comments.commentBody: You've no idea how terrified Europe is of infringing on someones human rights. Probably stems from the WW2 period. I honestly think Europe would rather have some of its citizens blown up in terrorist attacks than have the human rights of the terrorists infringed.
You assume that the countries you mention will accept these ideological time bombs born in the west.  Why should they?

But deportation requires breaking of a law.  To believe something is not a reason for deportation.  Causing harm is.  Our long history of prosecution is based on what a person has done, not on what they might do.

All of these people who have advocated terror, practiced it, or been trained to kill and maim for supposedly ideological/religious reasons should be deported and stripped of their EU citizenship.  They hate the West, but want to benefit from its educational system, health care, and, yes, relative safety and quality of life.  They ought to be happy to join their brethren in ISIL, or to request residence in Saudi Arabia, Pakistan, Yemn, Somalia, and a host of other places where they can take up "jihad" like good 7th century warriors and fight one another instead of gunning down the people they so despise in France, Spain, the Netherlands, wherever.

I am not making a claim that all people with mental health issues should be locked up.  In yet another case, my mother had a man with epilepsy that was then recurrent with all known treatments assist her with janitorial services at the store she operated on the hospital grounds.   The poor man nearly died after plummeting down a staircase during one such episode.  Perhaps today with all the newer medications, he'd be "out", too.

I disagree with you, as an artist who sometimes turns down clients if I don't think I can do a great job. It doesn't matter WHY I turn down that job, I am not a slave so I should not be forced to take a client I don't want.

Sometimes bakers have to design and bake specific cakes. Maybe the baker had a moral issue with gay marriage. Maybe they simply don't like the theme the bride has chosen. It doesn't matter.

Now, if it's a pre-baked cake, that's different. My thought on this - if you are selling a finished good, such as an already finished cake or a meal or socks - you cannot discriminate. But if you are asked to design a cake or cater a bachelor party or design a wedding dress - you can say no.

Besides, why would anyone want to hire someone who doesn't approve of them? I am in a mixed race marriage and I knew people who were against people marrying "outside the race". I would never have hired those people to cater my wedding, and I was glad to know who they were so I could avoid hiring them. When I got married, I wanted it to be a joyful event. I can't imagine gay people are any different!

Since none of Corvino's "cases" involve a refusal to bake a wedding cake, he muddies the water by dragging it into his conclusion. Corvino states: "[T]here’s a difference between being denied a portrait or a CAKE (emphasis added) and being denied, say, an apartment or a job."  Indeed, the difference is that refusing to bake a wedding cake is the clearest example of discrimination in his entire analysis. The only time spent with a customer is when taking and delivering the cake order. The only time the customer's sexual preference enters the production process is when you stick a plastic figure of a couple (same or opposite sex) on top of the cake. How hard is that? If a merchant can't handle the job without making a mountain out of a molehill, put him out of business. Case closed.

I've been making an icing like this for years.  Beat tgoether conf sugar and butter, then dribble in heavy cream, beating and adding cream until the mixture is very light and fluffy.  Or you can add cream cheese instead of some of the cream.  You can also add flavorings other than vanilla, like coffee, instead of some of the cream, grated rinds, etc.  Don't forget a dash of salt to bring out the flavor.

Could you clarify what you mean by productivity rate?  Productivity per worker hour is way up, though wages are flat.  Total value of national manufacturing output is down, because we offshored manufacturing.  And we have a glut of qualified Americans seeking work, especially in manufacturing, both because employers see a sustained lack of consumer demand, and because they make their products in China, not the U.S., these days.

Sorry, I meant:
Average annual % change of labor productivity that peaked around 2000.
2000-2007; 2.6%
2007-2014; 1.3%

Productivity isn't pay rate, and it isn't profitability. But productivity depends greatly on equipment. To boost productivity, investment in plant, equipment and infrastructure is needed, not greater human effort, not factors that give much advantage to younger workers. Has that investment been made at the same rate since the Great Recession? Probably not.

Prof. Krugman, could you explain about long-term decline of our productivity rate since late 1990's and also peaking out of our working-age population ratio in total during 2005-2010. Like Japan, it seems that the US has joined the aging economies. Therefore, I tend to see our low economic growth rate in recent years due to low productivity rate and peaking out of our working-age population. From this interpretation,  long-term trend of declining bond yield since 1990's makes sense for me. Am I wrong?

Just an hour ago, I heard the sad news during the course of "Minds Over Matter," a weekly call-in radio quiz show that originates on KALW, a San Francisco public radio station. Joshua Kosman, a constructor of cryptic for The Nation and music critic for the SF Chronicle, was on MOM's panel tonight -- as he is on an irregularly regular basis. A caller-in made a question out of Merl's death based on his name. I think Kosman may have been a bit taken aback by the question; perhapsI he didn't think a happy quiz show was the right place to bring up the sudden, shocking loss of a friend and colleague.

At any rate, that's how I found out. I haven't yet finished today's Merl -- and maybe I won't hurry to do do, to keep him with me a while longer.

How would raising interest rates, tipping the economy back into recession, driving up unemployment (not to mention lowering the employment to population ratio which has never recovered since The Great Recession began) do anything other than destroy the ability of its citizens to save for retirement, while drive pension funds bankrupt? From where I sit, you want to put the cart before the horse.

Thank you for this post. I think it might help for us not to talk about bodies, but rather about social norms for food at events. My sense is that most overweight kids know they are too heavy, but it's very hard for them to turn down food when we constantly offer it to them. Right now, it seems like it's unthinkable to have any event for kids without snacks and (even worse) juice. School parties always seem to require at least two desserts and an assortment of chips, with some fruit thrown in to make it "healthy." The omnipresence of food extends to adults too. Has anyone ever attended a book club or other nighttime social event where there weren't desserts and appetizers, even though it's 8pm, and presumably everyone has already had dinner? We should start a movement: unless an event occurs at mealtime, no food! We might find that the hosts are even relieved that they don't have to lay out a spread all the time, and it will be much easier for kids to eat healthily.

As a "good" student, and by good I mean I had a 4.0 when I left CC I find this comment offensive. The number of people that are trying to "scam" or "cheat" the system is relatively low compared to the overall number of students. In addition, what many instructors and administrators do not take into account is that the life of a low income student is complicated and fraught with endless roadblocks.

The FAFSA process at CC's is much more difficult than a University and absolutely more lengthy and confusing. There were times I spent as much time getting aid as I did in my classes. My CC was understaffed, under funded and the bureaucracy left what few full time faculty they employed confused and overwhelmed. This, in addition the the high number of adjunct instructors that are working at multiple colleges and universities makes for a pretty crazy atmosphere for a student to learn in. And lets not forget, we are talking about a large number of low income students of varying ages that may not have finished high school (like myself) and have little to no understanding of the college system.

In the end, practicing some empathy seems like a healthy choice. Studies show that angry people are at higher risk of health issues and most especially heart attacks. Please do be well.

I disagree. I have an 18 year old relative from a family with a substantial six figure income and large assets. She is beginning college this fall at a pricey private university and living on campus.

Her parents easily spend as much as her out of pocket tuition cost a year, on "toys", new vehicles and travel.

Why shouldn't they be expected to contribute to her college education?
So, the fact that a student's parents have millions should be irrelevant to a finncial aid decision?
Given that almost no high school seniors have significant income, disregarding all parental income would amount to waving a magic wand and making almost every student in need of scholarships.

The FAFSA should be ELIMINATED. There is no reason why a parent's information should even be factored into a student's financial aid package.  If a student is age 18, can vote, go to war and be tried as an adult in a court of law, they are an adult. Period. A parent's income is irrelevant. The FAFSA is the biggest scam yet and serves only to hook parents into co-signing private loans and parent plus loans. If a parent can help with a student's education, great, give them a tax credit, if not, ain't their education ain't their business.

Maybe someone here could explain how to use the energy created by a fusion reactor. If you take energy from the reaction you get entropy, so you would have to keep adding fuel.

The sun is so large that it will remain in its current state for a few more billion years, but how much space would you need for a reactor that would supply a city? The energy released by fusion, is certainly enormous, just a fission bomb only takes about a kilo of material, but a sustained fusion reaction will have to be contained by artificial gravity. In this case it is assumed magnetic fields can do it. It is possible there would be an event horizon as you would be trying to create a miniature black hole.

So again, you confine fusion within a tokamak,how do you use it, without liberating it?

You can file an estimate, however, they will not process your paperwork based on that at least at the community college here.  In fact, even when we did have our taxes done, we could not do the IRS data import because my husband was self employed and we had to pay taxes at the end of the year.  If you owe ANY money, the IRS will not process your taxes until the end of June.  This means that there was no year that I was able to have my information completed by the deadline.  Sure I could fill out the FAFSA and submit it, but my school did not consider it to be "completed" until the IRS processed my taxes.  Sadly even FA did not understand that if I could not do the data import online, I could not get a copy of my transcripts----both require the IRS to process the 1040.
